page.title: 03 Local History of Cwmbran
page.content: The name Cwmbran is reputed to have derived from "Bran", the father of Caradoc, although these days the English translation of Cwmbran is generally taken to be "Valley of the Crows". The Monmouthshire-Brecon canal runs behind our school and skirts the edge of the new town. It was built in 1792 and carried iron and coal to the docks in Newport. Llantarnam Abbey, a very historic building, is now a convent, and houses the Sisters of St. Joseph. It was once owned by R.J.Blewitt, an 18th century owner of the local iron works. During World War II it was used as a depot for the RAF.
